p: Similarly, Taheri et al. [ 76] studied the effect of extracts from A. sieberi, which showed antifungal activity against C. albicans, and prevented its growth. The results support the findings of our work. Indeed, the plant extract stopped the growth of C. albicans. Additionally, Gholampour-Azizi et al. [ 77], studied the in vitro antifungal activity of Cucumis melo and he demonstrated that it exhibited specific antifungal activity against C. albicans. Likewise, it has been demonstrated that aqueous and ethanolic extracts from T. polium showed an antifungal effect against C. albicans [ 78]. Furthermore, another study demonstrated that the aqueous extract of T. polium (2.5, 10, and 20 g/L) slows down the growth of Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Yarrowia lipolytica. In a recent study, Akbarzdeh et al. [ 79] studied the sensitivity of Candida strains against a T. polium smoke product. The authors demonstrated that all the standard clinical samples of Candida were sensitive. On the other hand, the result of the study of the antimicrobial activity of acetone and chloroform extracts from T. polium against four fungal species and eleven bacteria showed that the antibacterial effect is more significant than the antifungal activity, which is in concordance with our results [ 67, 73].
